dialog: Hi Medi, can you explain what is antigenic drift and antigenic shift?
Hello! Antigenic drift and shift are two ways that influenza viruses change over time
What is antigenic drift?
Antigenic drift is a gradual process that happens gradually over time. It's because of small changes in the virus's genes that happen when the virus replicates
What about antigenic shift?
Antigenic shift is a sudden and major change in the influenza virus. It happens when two different strains of the virus combine to create a new strain
Is it true that antigenic shift can lead to pandemics?
Yes, that's correct. When a new strain is created, people don't have immunity to it, and it can spread easily from person to person
That's really helpful. Thanks Medi!

Gastrointestinal symptoms may also occur, including nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and gastroenteritis, especially in children.  The standard influenza symptoms typically last for 2 - 8 days.   A 2021 study suggests influenza can cause long lasting symptoms in a similar way to long COVID. Symptomatic infections are usually mild and limited to the upper respiratory tract, but progression to pneumonia is relatively common Influenza Influenza

dialog: Hi Medi, can you explain to me what is antigenic shift in influenza viruses?

Sure, antigenic shift is the process by which two or more different strains of influenza virus combine to form a new subtype. This new subtype may have the ability to infect humans and cause a pandemic.
Interesting. What about antigenic drift?

Antigenic drift is a slower process than antigenic shift. It refers to small genetic mutations that occur in the influenza virus over time. This means that the virus is constantly changing and new vaccines need to be developed each year to keep up with the changes.
I see. Does this mean that getting the flu vaccine is useless?

No, getting the flu vaccine is still the best way to prevent getting the flu. Even though the vaccine may not be a perfect match for the virus, it can still reduce the severity of the illness and prevent complications.
Okay, thank you for the information, Medi.
You're welcome! Is there anything else I can assist you with?
No, that's all for now.

dialog: Hi Medi, I'm curious about the two key processes that influenza viruses evolve through. Can you explain them to me?
Of course! Influenza viruses evolve through antigenic drift and antigenic shift.
Can you explain what antigenic drift is?

Antigenic drift is a slow process that occurs over time as the virus mutates. The mutations are small, but they can accumulate over time and eventually result in a virus that is different enough from previous viruses that the immune system may not recognize it. This is why getting a flu shot every year is important, as it helps your body develop immunity to the latest strain of the virus.
And what about antigenic shift?

Antigenic shift is a sudden and dramatic change in the virus that occurs when two different strains of the virus infect the same host cell. This can lead to the creation of a new strain of the virus that is very different from previous strains, and the immune system may not be able to recognize it. This is how pandemics can occur, as happened with the H1N1 pandemic in 2009.
Wow, I didn't realize how complex the flu virus is. Thanks, Medi!
You're welcome! Do you have any other questions?
No, that's all for now. Thanks for your help!
